title: US Supreme Court temporarily preserves access to abortion pill
description: The decision by the nation's highest court means that mifepristone, which accounts for more than half of the abortions in the United States, will remain available while the case plays out in an appeals court.

title: Lithuania prepares to legalize the deportation of migrants
description: The law provides for the deportation of asylum seekers who have arrived illegally in the territory, and the creation of a civilian force to support the border guards.

title: Canadian public servants strike for right to work from home
description: Since Wednesday, April 19 – 155,000 Canadian federal employees have been on strike to demand wage increases in keeping with inflation and to be allowed to work from home.

title: French teen basketball phenom Victor Wembanyama declares for 2023 NBA Draft
description: Wembanyama is considered the top prospect since LeBron James, a player with speed and shotmaking skills like a guard but the size and strength of a center.

title: Manslaughter charges officially dropped against Alec Baldwin in fatal movie set shooting
description: A Los Angeles Times report said prosecutors had received information that the gun had been modified in a manner increasing the odds it might have misfired.

title: Street fighting in Sudan's capital eases as ceasefire declared for Eid al-Fitr
description: Witnesses in several areas of Khartoum reported a rare lull in the fighting Friday evening, after explosions had rocked the city for the seventh straight day.

title: Tahiti: The dark side of a tourist paradise
description: Social inequalities and poverty are high in French Polynesia, which is currently holding elections. Pro-independence parties may win for the first time.

title: Macron promotes an unlikely 'peace summit' for Ukraine
description: The French president is putting this idea forward with his foreign counterparts at the risk of causing more misunderstandings, and while Kyiv is focusing on its counter-offensive against Russian occupiers.

title: Paris court gives man life sentence for 1980 synagogue bombing
description: The bombing was the first deadly attack against a Jewish target on French soil since World War II.

title: In North Africa, political Islam recedes, to the benefit of governments
description: The repression of the Tunisian party Ennahda illustrates a major change in North Africa, which had seen the monopoly of religion escape government control.

title: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi neutralizes his main opponents
description: A court has refused to suspend the libel conviction of Rahul Gandhi, who will therefore not be able to compete against Modi in the 2024 general elections.

title: Olympic Games: Badminton keeps sanctions on Russians and Belarusians, archery drops ban
description: Sports federations have had to decide in recent weeks whether to allow Russians and Belrusians to take part in qualifying events for the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.

title: Strasbourg archbishop resigns amid accusations of poor governance
description: The decision, announced on Thursday and taken after the Vatican conducted an apostolic investigation, was eagerly awaited by the faithful and priests who reproached the archbishop for his authoritarianism.

title: PSG coach Galtier takes legal action on defamation and death threats after racism accusations
description: The coach has lodged complaints against two journalists and a former colleague, former Nice sporting director Julien Fournier, following allegations that he had made racist and Islamophobic comments about players.

title: Argentina's President Fernández won't run for re-election
description: The president announced in a video on social media he would not be running for a second term.

title: Comoros closes door to expelled migrants in standoff with France
description: The Indian Ocean nation has repeatedly expressed concern at the humanitarian and security risks of an upcoming operation to deport undocumented immigrants from the neighboring French overseas department of Mayotte.

title: UK sanctions officials behind arrest of Kremlin critic Kara-Murza
description: London on Friday imposed sanctions on five individuals and called on again for his immediate release.

title: Tesla triggers new electric car price war
description: The American carmaker lowered the prices of its cheapest models. This is the second time this year, and it is starting to pose a major problem for competitors.

title: Alibaba's magnate Jack Ma takes up Hong Kong university job
description: The billionaire had been keeping a low profile since late 2020 when he pronounced a speech attacking Chinese regulators.

title: Death of tormented K-pop star Moonbin shakes South Korea
description: The singer, model and actor took his own life at the age of 25. He was a leading figure in the country's music industry.

title: In Algeria, Ramadan TV series come to the rescue of a  film industry in tatters
description: Except for the month of fasting, no contemporary Algerian film is scheduled on private or public channels.

title: France must meet the challenge of debt reduction
description: After a long stalemate on the public deficit, due to the pandemic, the surge in energy prices and the inability to reduce public spending, France must restore its financial credibility.

title: A Russian spy in Paris: Bulat Yanborisov, rally organizer and high-flying Kremlin agent
description: Bulat Yanborisov is not just the director of the Silk Way Rally. Documents obtained by Der Spiegel, The Insider and Le Monde show that the Russian living in Paris is in fact a high-level Kremlin agent.

title: France refuses to provide Ukraine with maps to target Belarus
description: Kyiv asked Paris for a digital map of its neighbor's territory, which would allow fighter planes or drones to carry out low-altitude missions.

title: Demise of BuzzFeed News: 'The end of an era as imaginative as it was disconcerting'
description: The most famous of new media outlets announced it will close because it has not been able to find a sustainable economic model – one that pays and allows independence –writes columnist Philippe Escande.

title: Violence persits in Sudan as requests for Eid ceasefire ignored
description: More than 400 civilians have been killed and thousands injured since the fighting between two rival generals erupted on April 15.

title: France to continue subsidizing electricity bills until 2025
description: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire announced the extension as the country's electricity providers continue to suffer the effects of Russia's war in Ukraine.

title: Ukraine wants recognition and reparations for Russian 'ecocide'
description: In addition to the war's appalling human toll, there has been colossal environmental damage, which will have long-term health and humanitarian consequences.

title: Dominic Raab, UK's deputy prime minister, resigns in wake of bullying report
description: Dominic Raab says inquiry into his behavior 'has set a dangerous precedent for the conduct of a good government.'

title: French court jails four men for Champs Elysées terrorist plot
description: The trial dates back to a 2019 plan to attack policemen and possibly civilians on Paris's emblematic avenue.

title: Marches, storming Euronext, and banging pots: Pension reform opponents look to keep protests alive
description: Several actions were organized throughout Thursday, in the build-up to a Labor Day mobilization on May 1 that activists and unions hope will be historic.

title: MEPs vote in favor of EU migration and asylum pact
description: With the influx of undocumented migrants into Europe on the rise again since the end of 2022, the European Parliament has adopted its position on key texts for the migration and asylum package.

title: Sunni Muslims celebrate the start of Eid
description: While Muslims in many countries with a Sunni majority marked the end of their traditional month of fasting on Friday, those in countries with a Shiite majority had to wait until Saturday.

title: 'I loved Burkina Faso': A letter by expelled journalist Sophie Douce
description: Le Monde's correspondent in Burkina Faso was expelled in early April by the ruling military junta. In this very personal piece addressed to a friend in Ouagadougou, she reflects on the West African country where mass killings are being committed under the cover of operations against jihadists.

title: Marseille locals still 'traumatized' after building collapse
description: Ten days after the tragedy that killed eight residents in a central neighborhood, 300 people have still not returned to their homes.

title: Twitter puts an end to the old 'blue tick' certification
description: Since Thursday, only Twitter Blue subscribers can now display the authentication mark on their profile. Initiated by the platform in 2009, this system has since been imitated by most major social networks.

title: Paris 2024 Olympic Games: LVMH group enters the homestretch
description: Bernard Arnault, CEO of the luxury group, confirmed that he is negotiating a partnership contract for the Olympic Games to be held in Paris in 2024.

title: US House approves trans athlete ban for girls and women's teams
description: Pushed by House Republicans on Thursday – and checking off another high-profile item on their social agenda – the bill is unlikely to advance further.

title: Images generated by artificial intelligence: A new tool for disinformation
description: On social networks, photographs created entirely using artificial intelligence are starting to proliferate. Their use, while mainly satirical for the time being, could eventually threaten the truthfulness of public debate.
